pros: Work life balance, Flexible, Less pressure, Fair enough,

pros: The salary is decent for the work that is done. Apart from that, even if I like the position, there are not many other pros I would be able to highlight...
cons: Bureaucracy eats up too much time in general. Not enough focus on classes, but rather on organisation, coordination meetings, etc. Which is necessary but not what one is aiming for. THe right balance has not been found in that sense.

review_title: No stability at URJC, corruption everywhere
pros:
1- The campus has a lot of free space
2-I can't think on nothing else
cons:
1- Usually, the administrative staff are unprofessional, occasionally racist, and don't know their own duties
2- Wages are low compared to other universities in Europe
3- They have a Doctorate International School that never answers the emails, the staff doesn't speak another language other than Spanish, expensive tuition fees.
4- There is no prospect to professional growth in there, professionals are often hired with temporary contracts
5- Security is lacking, things are often stolen from our rooms.

pros: Time flexible job, also aloows the adquisition of skills like learning to work in a team, communication and writing, and project management.
cons: Working here with a partial time contract does not offer a high stability, and you have to have self learning skills and be independent

review_title: Groing university but needs to find a long term strategy
pros: Working from home when you have no class
cons:
In Spain professor wages at public universities are low, and since the economic crisis there have been no rises
The university have some management flaws that affect professor's working duties.
